thread.title: @TheNewsNomad - Cuban soldiers in Syria?, anger at Benghazi movie, death of Corey Jones, post-modernist apartment
thread.title_full: @TheNewsNomad - Cuban soldiers in Syria?, anger at Benghazi movie, death of Corey Jones, post-modernist apartment - Oximity

author: James Porteous
title: @TheNewsNomad - Cuban soldiers in Syria?, anger at Benghazi movie, death of Corey Jones, post-modernist apartment
text:
Welcome to @TheNewsNomad - a daily list of news and views that excite the imagination.
Curated by James Porteous
Read RYOT for more of my stories that fly below the radar
23 October 2015
Fox, Daily Beast Stories on Cubans in Syria Lack One Thing: Evidence of Cubans in Syria [FAIR]
Well, yes, "a Cuban troop presence in Syria would be a blockbuster story indeed—undermining the easing of tensions between Cuba and the United States while serving as a huge embarrassment for the Obama administration" but "there’s only one problem: The story is looking increasingly bunk." Although FAIR does conceded that it is "impossible to ever prove a negative, no one can "prove there are no Cuban soldiers in Syria, any more than one can prove there are not any members of the San Antonio Police Department or Nepalese Army there."
Angry Libyans slam Michael Bay's Benghazi attack thriller [The Guardian]
The first trailer for Michael Bay's upcoming thriller "13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi" is said to have caused an uproar in Libya, with government officials, bloggers and Facebook users lining up to criticise the film. The film is the story of "a six-man US security team who fought to defend the American diplomatic compound in Benghazi following an attack by radical Islamist terrorists on September 11 2012." The trailer shows the team battling to save “36 American lives in the face of gun-toting insurgents on the streets of Benghazi (though the film was in fact shot in Malta), against a backdrop of exploding vehicles and flaming buildings." But, Libya’s culture and information minister Omar Gawaari told the Associated Press, the movie shows the US contractors “who actually failed to secure the ambassador ... as heroes”, adding that Bay “turned America’s failure to protect its own citizens in a fragile state into a typical action movie all about American heroism."
Hurricanes Wreak Economic Havoc as World Warms [Climate News Network]
Analysis of insurance data appears to indicate that global warming "could already be costing the US billions of dollars each year in hurricane damage alone." Economists believe that somewhere between $2bn and $14bn of the financial costs of hurricane damage in 2005 could be attributed to the impact of global warming. The economists also "see the fingerprint not of climate variability − the meteorological throw of the dice that sends a hurricane to a city centre rather than a deserted coast − but of underlying climate change." And that was 2005. What might the total be in 2015?
Corey Jones didn't fire his gun, attorney says [Various]
Add another name to the growing list of seemingly innocent people killed by police. Florida drummer Corey Jones was awaiting a tow truck after a show when he encountered Norman Raja, a plainclothes police officer. Details are of course sketchy but early reports indicate that he may have had a (legal) gun and he may not have known Raja was a cop.
Bandmate Mathew Huntsberger told The Washington Post that he left Jones at around 2:30 a.m. Roughly 45 minutes later, Jones was dead. “When I left him he was sitting in his car calling roadside assistance. I never would have thought that someone was going to come kill him,” Huntsberger said.
Brooklyn Museum Has a Pristine Postmodernist Apartment Tucked Away in Storage [Observer]
"Oh, the treasures that can be found in museum storage! Word trickled out recently that the Brooklyn Museum has been hiding something very special: a rare example of Postmodernist residential architecture has been tucked away in a warehouse for nearly three decades. A completely intact apartment by American Postmodern architect Michael Graves has been in storage at the Brooklyn Museum since it was acquired in 1986. Similar to other Postmodern designs by Graves, the apartment features ornamental design, an eclectic blend of classical references and muted color palettes."
Obviously Drivers Are Already Abusing Tesla’s Autopilot [Wired]
And so it begins in earnest. Although Tesla's Autopilot is intended for highway usage only, there is apparently no means to stop anyone who wants to do pretty-much whatever they want to do with it. So a Tesla Model S P85D was used to drive across the country in record time for an EV, and Tesla owners are posting videos of themselves driving with theirs hands off the wheel, sometimes with hairy results like being pulled over for speeding and nearly steering into an oncoming car. Another video is featured on this page.
James Porteous is editor and curator of @TheNewsNomad , a daily list of stories that might be overlooked by the mainstream media and a Contributing Writer for RYOT .
